newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine Congress backs bill to jail tax evaders.
newsitem.headline: Argentine Congress backs bill to jail tax evaders.

text.p: The lower house of the Argentine Congress gave its general approval late on Wednesday to a bill to introduce prison sentences of up to nine years for big-time tax evaders.
The bill, sponsored by the Peronist government's majority, was given general approval by 95 deputies, with 59 votes against and four abstentions.
Deputies then began debating the bill on a point-by-point basis. It goes next to the Senate, where the Peronists also have a majority, for final debate before becoming law.
President Carlos Menem wants harsh terms for tax cheats to help him combat tax evasion, which he estimates runs at $20 billion a year -- or nearly half Argentina's annual budget.
Omar Menem, deputy head of the Chamber of Deputies' Penal Leglislation Committee, said it was necessary to implement in Argentina "a new tax culture" to stop endemic tax dodging.
The draft bill approved at the committee stage foresees the maximum jail term of nine years for people who cheat the tax office out of more than $1 million in one tax year.
